articles.title: Home-field advantage: how local research leads to new discoveries
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03980-yBy studying caves near his home in Johannesburg, South Africa, geologist Tebogo Makhubela ventures into places people have never been before.
articles.content:
“The Cradle of Humankind is a complex system of limestone caves that has the world’s highest concentration of ancient human fossils. It’s located about 50 kilometres northwest of Johannesburg, South Africa. When I started working there as a PhD student ten years ago, I never thought that I would be the person making discoveries. I always saw myself as a support person who helped the palaeontologists and archaeologists.

Now, I work as a senior geologist at four sites in the Cradle of Humankind, and the more time I spend there, the more I realize how much is still unknown in the field of geology. Before 2013, none of the geology research here was done by local researchers. Instead, people would fly in from the United States, Australia and France for a week, map a section of cave where fossils were excavated, collect samples and then do their analyses abroad.

This photo was taken in the Rising Star Cave, which was mined heavily from around the early 1900s until the late 1940s. Researchers typically look for blocks of rock left over from mining activity, because that’s where the fossils tend to be, but one day my team and I decided to investigate what we thought was the bedrock. We eventually broke through to discover some of the best fossils we’ve found so far, along with missing skeletal elements from other fossil pieces that had been found closer to the surface.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights significant scientific discoveries made by local researchers in the Cradle of Humankind caves, marking a shift from foreign-led to local-led research. This represents a meaningful advancement in paleontology and geology with broad cultural and scientific impact, inspiring local empowerment and new knowledge about human origins.
articles.personality_title: Local scientists uncover new fossils in South Africa’s famous caves
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Cradle of Humankind is a group of limestone caves located about 50 kilometers northwest of Johannesburg, South Africa. It holds the highest number of ancient human fossils in the world. For many years, researchers from other countries studied the caves, but local scientists were not involved in leading the work.

**What happened** – Tebogo Makhubela, a geologist from Johannesburg, started working in these caves as a PhD student ten years ago. He has now become a senior geologist leading research at four sites in the area. Recently, his team explored a part of the cave thought to be just bedrock and discovered important new fossils and missing bones that had not been found before.

**Impact** – This discovery shows how local scientists can make important breakthroughs when given the opportunity to lead research. It changes the way scientists study the Cradle of Humankind and helps us learn more about early human history. It also encourages more local experts to take part in studying their own country’s natural heritage.

**What's next step** – Tebogo and his team will continue exploring the caves to find more fossils and better understand the geology of the area. Their work may reveal new details about how ancient humans lived and evolved. This local-led research could inspire similar efforts in other important sites around the world.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A South African geologist’s local knowledge helped uncover new ancient human fossils, showing the value of local scientists leading research in their own regions.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques locaux découvrent de nouveaux fossiles dans les célèbres grottes d’Afrique du Sud

**Contexte** – Le Berceau de l’Humanité est un ensemble de grottes calcaires situées à environ 50 kilomètres au nord-ouest de Johannesburg, en Afrique du Sud. Il contient la plus grande concentration de fossiles humains anciens au monde. Pendant longtemps, les recherches étaient menées par des scientifiques étrangers, sans que les chercheurs locaux dirigent les études.

Il est maintenant géologue principal sur quatre sites de la région. Récemment, son équipe a exploré une zone considérée comme du simple socle rocheux et a découvert des fossiles importants et des os manquants qui n’avaient jamais été trouvés.

**Impact** – Cette découverte montre que les scientifiques locaux peuvent réaliser des avancées majeures lorsqu’ils dirigent les recherches. Cela change la manière d’étudier le Berceau de l’Humanité et aide à mieux comprendre l’histoire des premiers humains. Cela encourage aussi plus d’experts locaux à participer à l’étude du patrimoine naturel de leur pays.

**Prochaine étape** – Tebogo et son équipe vont continuer à explorer les grottes pour trouver plus de fossiles et mieux comprendre la géologie du site. Leur travail pourrait révéler de nouveaux détails sur la vie et l’évolution des premiers humains. Cette recherche menée localement pourrait inspirer d’autres projets similaires ailleurs dans le monde.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – La connaissance locale d’un géologue sud-africain a permis de découvrir de nouveaux fossiles anciens, montrant l’importance des chercheurs locaux pour diriger les études dans leur région.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos locales descubren nuevos fósiles en las famosas cuevas de Sudáfrica
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Cuna de la Humanidad es un grupo de cuevas de piedra caliza ubicadas a unos 50 kilómetros al noroeste de Johannesburgo, Sudáfrica. Contiene la mayor concentración de fósiles humanos antiguos del mundo. Durante muchos años, investigadores extranjeros estudiaron las cuevas, pero los científicos locales no lideraban los trabajos.

**Qué pasó** – Tebogo Makhubela, un geólogo de Johannesburgo, comenzó a trabajar en estas cuevas hace diez años como estudiante de doctorado. Ahora es geólogo principal y lidera la investigación en cuatro sitios del área. Recientemente, su equipo exploró una zona que pensaban era solo roca base y descubrieron fósiles importantes y huesos faltantes que no se habían encontrado antes.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento muestra que los científicos locales pueden hacer avances importantes cuando tienen la oportunidad de liderar la investigación. Cambia la forma en que se estudia la Cuna de la Humanidad y nos ayuda a conocer más sobre la historia de los primeros humanos. También anima a más expertos locales a participar en el estudio del patrimonio natural de su país.

**Próximos pasos** – Tebogo y su equipo seguirán explorando las cuevas para encontrar más fósiles y entender mejor la geología del área. Su trabajo podría revelar nuevos detalles sobre cómo vivían y evolucionaban los humanos antiguos. Esta investigación liderada localmente podría inspirar esfuerzos similares en otros sitios importantes del mundo.

**Frase clave** – El conocimiento local de un geólogo sudafricano ayudó a descubrir nuevos fósiles humanos antiguos, mostrando el valor de que los científicos locales lideren la investigación en sus regiones.

articles.title: Christine Lagarde: Days remain until Bulgaria joins the eurozone
articles.summary: From December 1, starter kits with Bulgarian euro coins are on sale in the country
articles.content:
From December 1, starter kits with Bulgarian euro coins are on sale in the country

FRANKFURT/SOFIA – Bulgaria is in the final stage of long and persistent efforts, emphasized on Sunday the President of the European Central Bank Christine Lagarde in a post on social media.

Only 25 days remain until Bulgaria’s accession to the euro area, Lagarde wrote on “Facebook”.

On 1 December, when in Bulgaria the sale of starter kits with euro coins with a Bulgarian national side began, Lagarde also published a message on the topic on her profile.

One month until Bulgaria’s accession to the euro and the new Bulgarian coins are heading towards the euro area, Lagarde noted then.

The Bulgarian Prime Minister Rossen Zhelyazkov, together with the Governor of the Bulgarian National Bank Dimitar Radev, became acquainted with the production process of the Bulgarian euro coins at the BNB Mint.

The Bulgarian euro coins will be legal tender throughout Europe and will bear Bulgarian national symbols. Thus our country will be part of the European cultural and monetary heritage, said Prime Minister Zhelyazkov.

He noted that all euro coins have the same obverse side for the whole of Europe, and on the other side – national symbols characteristic of each euro area member state.

The Bulgarian series of euro coins includes established national symbols, figures and sites from the national history and cultural heritage of the country. On the coin with a denomination of 2 euro Paisiy Hilendarski is depicted – a Bulgarian monk, clergyman and educator, author of the Revival-era work “Istoriya slavyanobalgarska”, the coin with a denomination of 1 euro presents the image of Saint Ivan Rilski – a spiritual leader, hermit and miracle worker, considered the heavenly protector of the Bulgarian people. The coins with a denomination of 50, 20, 10, 5 and 2 cents bear the image of the Madara Rider – a rock relief from the 8th century, included in the World Cultural Heritage List.

From 1 December in the country the sale began of starter kits with Bulgarian euro coins for citizens and businesses. The kit for individuals consists of 42 euro coins of all denominations with a total value of 10 euro and 23 cents and is sold at a price of 20 leva for one starter kit. (7.12.2025)
articles.reasoning: The article reports Bulgaria's upcoming accession to the eurozone, a significant economic and political milestone with broad impact on the country and Europe. It highlights the cultural integration through national symbols on euro coins and the launch of starter kits for citizens, indicating a tangible and meaningful change. The story is focused, detailed, and represents a positive development for Bulgaria and the European Union.
articles.personality_title: Bulgaria prepares to join the eurozone with new euro coins available from December 1
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Bulgaria has been working for many years to join the eurozone, the group of European countries that use the euro as their currency. This change means Bulgaria will switch from its own currency, the lev, to the euro.

**What happened** – On December 1, Bulgaria started selling starter kits containing euro coins with special Bulgarian designs. These coins will soon become the official money in Bulgaria, and the country will officially join the eurozone in about 25 days. The kits include all euro coin types and show important Bulgarian symbols like the Madara Rider, Saint Ivan Rilski, and Paisiy Hilendarski.

**Impact** – This is a big step for Bulgaria because it connects the country more closely with other European nations economically and culturally. Using the euro will make trade and travel easier with other eurozone countries. The coins also celebrate Bulgaria’s history and culture, showing the country’s unique identity within Europe.

**What's next step** – Bulgaria will officially become part of the eurozone in early December. Citizens and businesses will start using the euro coins and notes as their normal money. Over time, the lev will be replaced by the euro in all daily transactions.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Bulgaria is about to join the eurozone, launching special euro coins that honor its culture while making the euro its new currency starting this December.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Bulgarie se prépare à rejoindre la zone euro avec de nouvelles pièces en euros disponibles dès le 1er décembre
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La Bulgarie travaille depuis de nombreuses années à rejoindre la zone euro, le groupe de pays européens utilisant l’euro comme monnaie. Ce changement signifie que la Bulgarie abandonnera son propre lev pour adopter l’euro.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 1er décembre, la Bulgarie a commencé à vendre des kits de départ contenant des pièces en euros avec des dessins spéciaux bulgares. Ces pièces deviendront bientôt la monnaie officielle en Bulgarie, qui rejoindra la zone euro dans environ 25 jours. Les kits comprennent toutes les pièces en euros et montrent des symboles importants de la Bulgarie comme le Cavalier de Madara, Saint Ivan Rilski et Paisiy Hilendarski.

**Impact** – C’est une grande étape pour la Bulgarie car elle rapproche le pays des autres nations européennes sur le plan économique et culturel. Utiliser l’euro facilitera le commerce et les voyages avec les autres pays de la zone euro. Les pièces célèbrent aussi l’histoire et la culture bulgares, montrant l’identité unique du pays en Europe.

**Prochaine étape** – La Bulgarie deviendra officiellement membre de la zone euro début décembre. Les citoyens et les entreprises commenceront à utiliser les pièces et billets en euros comme monnaie courante. Progressivement, le lev sera remplacé par l’euro dans toutes les transactions quotidiennes.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La Bulgarie s’apprête à rejoindre la zone euro en lançant des pièces en euros spéciales qui honorent sa culture, faisant de l’euro sa nouvelle monnaie dès décembre.
articles.personality_title_es: Bulgaria se prepara para unirse a la zona euro con nuevas monedas disponibles desde el 1 de diciembre
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Bulgaria ha estado trabajando durante muchos años para unirse a la zona euro, el grupo de países europeos que usan el euro como moneda. Este cambio significa que Bulgaria dejará su propia moneda, el lev, para usar el euro.

**Qué pasó** – El 1 de diciembre, Bulgaria comenzó a vender kits de inicio con monedas en euros que tienen diseños especiales búlgaros. Estas monedas pronto serán el dinero oficial en Bulgaria, que se unirá a la zona euro en unos 25 días. Los kits incluyen todas las monedas en euros y muestran símbolos importantes de Bulgaria como el Jinete de Madara, San Iván Rilski y Paisiy Hilendarski.

**Impacto** – Este es un paso importante para Bulgaria porque conecta al país más cerca de otras naciones europeas en lo económico y cultural. Usar el euro facilitará el comercio y los viajes con otros países de la zona euro. Las monedas también celebran la historia y cultura de Bulgaria, mostrando la identidad única del país dentro de Europa.

**Próximo paso** – Bulgaria se convertirá oficialmente en parte de la zona euro a principios de diciembre. Los ciudadanos y negocios comenzarán a usar las monedas y billetes en euros como dinero normal. Con el tiempo, el lev será reemplazado por el euro en todas las transacciones diarias.

**Una frase clave** – Bulgaria está a punto de unirse a la zona euro, lanzando monedas especiales que honran su cultura mientras hacen del euro su nueva moneda a partir de este diciembre.
